title: Fourth fuel-queue death in Sri Lanka in under 48 hours
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The death of a 76-year-old at a fuel queue in crisis-riddled Sri Lanka has brought the fuel line death toll to four in under 48 hours, police reports confirm.

The incident took place at 7.30 am on Monday (21) at a petrol station in Mirigama, in Sri Lanka’s western province. The victim, a resident of Nawana, was loading filled petrol barrels into his threewheeler when he collapsed, police said.
This is the fourth death that occurred at a fuel queue in under 48 hours. Three of the deaths have been of senior citizens over the age of 70.
Man stabbed to death in fuel queue in Sri Lanka; third fuel queue death in 48 hours

Posts have been circulating on social media about people fainting from the heat as they wait in line for gas, diesel, and other essentials. On Sunday (20) News First reported that Minister of Energy Gamini Lokuge had advised a limit to the number of fuel cans that can be filled per person, in order to combat the ongoing crisis.
Sri Lanka is currently facing a fuel shortage due to a forex crisis, and high prices due to a sharp devaluation of the rupee following a decision to let the currency float. (Colombo/Mar21/2022)
